par.text: Gadolinium is a silver-white, malleable and ductile metal. It belongs to the lanthanide series of elements. Gadolinium is ferromagnetic - meaning it has the ability to become strongly magnetised in a magnetic field. This ability is lost above a certain temperature (termed the Curie point), which in the case of gadolinium is found to be about 20
C. Gadolinium combines with oxygen to form the white gadolinium oxide, G
. At elevated temperatures gadolinium reacts with water to produce gadolinium hydroxide - Gd(OH

- and hydrogen. It displaces hydrogen from acids to form salts. Gadolinium was discovered in 1880 by the Swiss chemists Jean de Marignac and Lecoq de Boisbaudran. The element was named after the mineral gadolinite, which in turn was named after the Finnish chemist Johan Gadolin.
